Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit
RNAs are remarkable because they can be both information carriers and structured functional macromolecules. They play a wide variety of roles in biology, including in gene expression regulation by riboswitches. Riboswitches are metabolite-dependent functional RNAs composed of aptamer domains and expression platforms, which bind small-molecule targets and regulate gene expression, respectively. Most riboswitches have been found in bacteria, with a single example known in plants, fungi, and algae, where it regulates alternative splicing and transcript stability. To discover more eukaryotic riboswitches, small-molecule aptamers need to be mapped out and tested for regulatory functions. Recently, adenosine aptamers were discovered in the human genome and preliminary results indicate that they sense ATP through a kinetic mechanism. The objective of this project is to measure the distribution of a variety of metabolite aptamers in genetic model eukaryotes. The aptamers will be detected using in vitro selections from a metagenomic genomic library and tested for potential roles as riboswitches. Adenosine aptamers, together with new aptamers found using SELEX will be tested for gene regulatory functions. Altogether, this research will contribute to the fundamental understanding of eukaryotic RNA biology and help define the roles that non-coding functional RNAs play in gene regulation and other cellular mechanisms.

Broader impacts
This project will enhance our understanding of regulatory roles that RNAs play in eukaryotic model organisms, including plants. Throughout the project period undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in molecular and cellular biosciences, providing them with sets of broadly applicable problem-solving skills on both in both experimental and computational biology. In addition, a large numbers of young students from local middle schools, many of them from backgrounds that do not emphasize education and from schools that lack the resources for laboratory experimentation, will be exposed to the thrill of molecular biology to encourage them to consider higher education in the sciences

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project set out to map the distribution of aptamers in genetic model organisms. We first constructed a large metagenmic DNA library composed of genomes of all major model eukaryotes, including plants, fungi, insects, worms, fish, and mammals. This library, together with a previously-prepared human library, was used as the starting material for in vitro selections to enrich those sequences capable of binding the various target metabolites and signaling molecules, such as ATP and cyclic-GMP. To facilitate the discovery of true aptamers, we also applied a chemical modification technique called SHAPE, coupled with high-throughput sequencing, to discover and characterize bona-fide aptamers directly within the selected pools – that is, without the need for isolation and characterization of individual sequences. This technique, called Apta-Seq, reveals in a single deep-sequencing run the identity, structural features (including putative conformational changes), and binding constants of the majority of aptamers present in the selected pools. Using this technique we uncovered three new adenosine/ATP binding aptamers in the human genome and several potential aptamers for cGMP. Furthermore, we published RNArobo – a highly-efficient program for the bioinformatic discovery of previously-characterized RNA folds. Finally, in related projects, we found that a bacterial self-cleaving ribozyme's activity is allosterically modulated by glucosamine-6-phosphate, the substrate of the downstream gene product; we uncovered the smallest HDV-like ribozymes and characterized the role of a peripheral domain on the activity of the largest ribozymes of this family; we found that DNA can be replicated by various DNA polymerases using diphosphorylated substrates and that the reaction is reversible; and we constructed a ribozyme that acts as a tRNA amino acylase using a bioorthogonal reaction. The results have been disseminated in peer-reviewed research articles, reviews, conference talks and posters, and departmental seminars. The PI also served as a Guest Editor of an issue of Methods focused on in vitro selection and evolution techniques.

Throughout the length of the project, five graduate students and four undergraduate students were directly trained to perform genomic SELEX experiments. Another five graduate students and a postdoctoral fellow have been trained in other types of selection experiments. In addition, several hundred undergraduates were trained in molecular evolution, particularly SELEX experiments, through the Principal Investigator's teaching activities. Moreover the Luptak research group hosted middle-school students and teachers from Santa Ana schools, where the vast majority of students come from underrepresented minorities, for demonstration project exemplifying research activities at a major research university. The lab hosted these students at least twice each year.
